Strangely enough, despite the explorative nature of much of his music, Hancock was also quite accessible, recording the future hit Ã¢â‚¬Å“Watermelon ManÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ on his debut date. In addition, there are a dozen alternate takes (seven not previously released), five selections taken from dates led by others (Donald Byrd, Jackie McLean, Wayne Shorter, and Bobby Hutcherson), and an unissued R&B-ish number (Ã¢â‚¬Å“DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t Ever Go ThereÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½) from an abandoned 1966 project. The title of the attractive 1998 package is not completely accurate, for although the program includes all of HancockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Blue Note dates as a leader, it does not have all of his recordings as a sideman for the label (which would take a really huge box). Among HancockÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sidemen are trumpeters Freddie Hubbard, Donald Byrd, Thad Jones, and Johnny Coles, tenors Dexter Gordon, Hank Mobley, and Joe Henderson, bassists Butch Warren, Chuck Israels, Paul Chambers, Ron Carter, and Buster Williams, and drummers Billy Higgins, Tony Williams, Willie Bobo, Mickey Roker, and Albert Ã¢â‚¬Å“TootieÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ Heath.
